title: Hearing versus Auditory Processing Disorders: Are Hearing Aids Enough?
chief_complaint: I have trouble understanding soft speech and communicating in noisy places. I tried hearing aids twice, but they just made the background noise louder and more annoying without helping me understand what people were saying.

problem_summary.onset: Noticed significant issues at age 40; retrospective history suggests difficulties since high school.
problem_summary.course: Symptoms persisted and worsened over 7 years despite hearing aid trials; led to social withdrawal.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Difficulty understanding speech in noise, annoyance with amplified noise.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Withdrew from social situations to avoid the struggle of understanding conversations; work performance affected as demands increased.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Wants to understand why he cannot hear well despite 'normal' hearing tests and failed hearing aid trials.

encounters.setting: Audiology Clinic (Comprehensive Audiologic and APD Assessment)

history.present_illness: Patient reports 7-year history of difficulty understanding speech, especially in noise. Multiple previous evaluations found normal hearing (except mild loss at 8k Hz).
history.otologic_history: Previous normal ABR and MRI. Normal tympanometry and acoustic reflexes.
history.medical_psych_history: Normal neurologic findings. Normal language and cognitive-linguistic evaluation by SLP.
history.prior_management: Two separate hearing aid trials (one with noise reduction) failed; patient returned devices because noise was louder and annoying.
history.patient_goals: Determine the cause of hearing difficulties.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Hearing within normal limits 250-4000 Hz; mild sensorineural hearing loss at 8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise (W-22)
tests.key_findings: Significant rollover/deficit in noise compared to quiet. Results outside normal limits for quiet/noise difference.

tests.name: SCAN-3A (Auditory Processing Battery)
tests.key_findings: Abnormal results in Auditory Figure-Ground, Filtered Words, and Competing Words. Normal results for Competing Sentences and Time Compressed Sentences.

tests.name: Staggered Spondaic Word (SSW) Test
tests.key_findings: Significant integration deficits noted for the Left Competing (LC) condition and abnormal Ear Effect (Low/High).

history.present_illness: Patient returned for re-evaluation after 1 year of auditory training (DOT program and SIN training).

numeric_results.Result: Scaled scores of 9 (37th percentile) or better for all measures

overall_audiologic_summary: Peripheral hearing sensitivity is essentially normal (mild loss only at 8 kHz), and speech recognition in quiet is excellent (100%). However, comprehensive APD testing reveals significant deficits in auditory integration (dichotic listening) and speech understanding in noise (W-22 in noise, SCAN-3A Figure-Ground). Temporal processing and phonological synthesis abilities are intact. The profile is consistent with an Auditory Processing Disorder affecting integration and figure-ground skills.
counseling_points: Your standard hearing test is normal, which is why hearing aids made things louder but not clearer.
The testing shows you have an Auditory Processing Disorder (APD). Your brain struggles to separate speech from background noise and to integrate information from both ears.
This is likely a long-standing issue that you were able to compensate for until work demands increased.
Since hearing aids are not the solution, we need to focus on auditory training and strategies to help your brain process sound more efficiently.
notes_for_actor: Portray frustration with the medical system; you have seen multiple doctors who told you 'nothing is wrong' while you struggle daily.
